articles.title: New NASA HEAT and My NASA Data Resources Bring Space Weather Science into Classrooms
articles.summary: As the Sun enters a period of heightened activity, students now have a new way to explore its powerful effects on Earth and space. NASA’s Heliophysics Education Activation Team (NASA HEAT), in collaboration with My NASA Data, has released a new set of classroom resources that invite students and educators to engage with real NASA […]
articles.content:
Space weather is an important part of the Sun's interaction with the space around it. Scientists called heliophysicists study these phenomena to help us better understand how and why it happens, and the effects it can have on the rest of our solar system.

As the Sun enters a period of heightened activity, students now have a new way to explore its powerful effects on Earth and space. NASA’s Heliophysics Education Activation Team (NASA HEAT), in collaboration with My NASA Data, has released a new set of classroom resources that invite students and educators to engage with real NASA mission data to study space weather phenomena in real time.

Hands-On Learning with Real NASA Data

Developed as part of NASA HEAT’s mission to increase awareness and understanding of heliophysics, these new materials help learners connect directly with the science of the Sun and its influence on the solar system. The resources include:

Lesson plans and mini-lessons for quick classroom engagement

Interactive web-based tools that let students visualize and analyze real mission data

StoryMaps, longer-form digital experiences that guide multi-day investigations into space weather events

These activities draw from data collected by NASA’s Parker Solar Probe, the Solar Dynamics Observatory (SDO), and the European Space Agency’s Solar Orbiter, among others, giving students a chance to explore how scientists monitor and study the Sun’s behavior.

Understanding Space Weather

Space weather is driven by the Sun’s activity – its bursts of energy, radiation, and plasma that stream through space. When these events interact with Earth’s magnetic field, they can produce stunning auroras but also cause radio disruptions, satellite interference, and power grid issues.

By engaging with these new resources, students can learn how NASA monitors and predicts these solar phenomena and why studying space weather is essential for keeping astronauts, spacecraft, and technology safe.

Learning During Solar Maximum

This launch comes at a perfect time. In late 2024, the Sun entered solar maximum, the most active part of its 11-year cycle, providing students a front-row seat to increased solar flares, sunspots, and coronal mass ejections. The new NASA HEAT and My NASA Data resources encourage educators to use this unique moment to deepen classroom discussions on magnetism, energy, and the Sun–Earth connection through observation and data-driven exploration.

Inspiring Future Scientists

Both NASA HEAT and My NASA Data, part of GLOBE Mission Earth (Global Learning and Observations to Benefit the Environment), are part of the NASA Science Activation (SciAct) program, which connects learners of all ages with authentic NASA science content, experts, and experiences. By bringing real-world data and current scientific phenomena into the classroom, these new tools empower students to think like scientists and see themselves as contributors to ongoing discovery.

Explore the New Resources

It has a clear positive impact by enhancing STEM education with authentic data, timed with the solar maximum for relevance, and provides detailed context about the tools and their significance.
articles.personality_title: NASA launches new tools for students to study the Sun’s space weather in real time
articles.personality_presentation:

These include lesson plans, interactive websites, and digital guides that use real data from NASA missions like the Parker Solar Probe and Solar Dynamics Observatory. They let students explore space weather events as they happen.

articles.title: NASA Citizen Science Toolkit for Librarians
articles.summary: NASA’s Toolkit for Librarians can help you share NASA citizen science opportunities with your patrons and community members. Rural and urban libraries, informal educators, youth group leaders, and retirement community coordinators can all benefit from this resource. Together, we can open the door for more people to join the fun, learning, and thrill of doing NASA science.
articles.content:
Librarians: NASA Citizen Science has something for you!

Our new Toolkit for Librarians can help you share NASA citizen science opportunities with your patrons and community members. Rural and urban libraries, informal educators, youth group leaders, and retirement community coordinators can all benefit from this resource. Together, we can open the door for more people to join the fun, learning, and thrill of doing NASA science.

The toolkit prepares a program leader to lead a NASA Science event for people ages 8 and up. The toolkit includes:

A guide to help you prepare for the event, from choosing and equipping the space, to becoming familiar with the citizen science project that will be the focus of the event

An editable 8.5” by 11” poster to advertise your event

A model agenda to follow during your event

A handout for you and your participants to help you explore NASA-sponsored citizen science project opportunities

The toolkit creators, Sarah Kirn (Participatory Science Strategist, NASA, from the Gulf of Maine Research Institute) and Kara Reiman (librarian), together with NASA’s Citizen Science Officer Marc Kuchner, also recorded a video walk-through of this Toolkit.

"I appreciate this so much!” said one participant. “I have started Citizen Science Kits for circulation over this past year and am excited to share new opportunities with our patrons!"

"Living in a very rural and primarily native community, the kids here are limited with their nearby opportunities, so sharing this with them is a huge win…” said another.
articles.reasoning: The article describes a NASA initiative that provides librarians and community leaders with a toolkit to engage diverse populations in NASA citizen science projects. This promotes science education and participation broadly across rural and urban communities, fostering public involvement in space science. The resource has tangible benefits for education and inclusion, with detailed support materials and positive community feedback.
articles.personality_title: NASA offers toolkit to help librarians share citizen science projects
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – NASA wants more people to join its citizen science projects, where regular people help with real NASA research. To do this, they created a special toolkit for librarians and community leaders.

**What happened** – NASA released a Toolkit for Librarians that helps them organize events about NASA citizen science. The toolkit includes guides for planning, posters to advertise, schedules to follow, and handouts about NASA projects. It is designed for people aged 8 and older and works for libraries in cities and rural areas, youth groups, and retirement communities.

**Impact** – This toolkit makes it easier for librarians and educators to bring NASA science to their communities, including places where kids and adults might not have many science activities nearby. People who have used the toolkit say it helps them offer new learning opportunities and get more people excited about space science.

**What’s next step** – Librarians and community leaders can start using the toolkit to hold NASA citizen science events. NASA also provides a video to help guide them. This may lead to more people, especially young learners, becoming involved in real scientific work with NASA.

**One-sentence takeaway** – NASA’s new toolkit helps librarians bring exciting citizen science projects to communities everywhere, making space science more accessible and fun.
articles.personality_title_fr: La NASA propose un kit pour aider les bibliothécaires à partager des projets de science participative
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – La NASA souhaite que plus de personnes participent à ses projets de science participative, où le grand public contribue à de vraies recherches. Pour cela, elle a créé un kit spécial pour les bibliothécaires et les responsables communautaires.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – La NASA a lancé un kit pour bibliothécaires qui les aide à organiser des événements sur la science participative de la NASA. Le kit comprend des guides pour la préparation, des affiches pour faire de la publicité, des plannings à suivre et des documents d’information sur les projets de la NASA. Il s’adresse aux personnes dès 8 ans et convient aux bibliothèques urbaines et rurales, aux groupes de jeunes et aux communautés de retraités.

**Impact** – Ce kit facilite l’accès à la science de la NASA pour les bibliothécaires et éducateurs, notamment dans les endroits où les activités scientifiques sont rares. Ceux qui l’ont utilisé disent qu’il leur permet de proposer de nouvelles opportunités d’apprentissage et de faire découvrir la science spatiale à plus de monde.

**Prochaine étape** – Les bibliothécaires et responsables peuvent commencer à utiliser ce kit pour organiser des événements de science participative. La NASA fournit aussi une vidéo explicative. Cela pourrait encourager davantage de personnes, surtout les jeunes, à participer à de véritables travaux scientifiques avec la NASA.

**Message clé en une phrase** – Le nouveau kit de la NASA aide les bibliothécaires à rendre les projets de science participative accessibles et amusants dans toutes les communautés.
articles.personality_title_es: La NASA ofrece un kit para ayudar a bibliotecarios a compartir proyectos de ciencia ciudadana
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – La NASA quiere que más personas participen en sus proyectos de ciencia ciudadana, donde el público ayuda en investigaciones reales. Para lograrlo, creó un kit especial para bibliotecarios y líderes comunitarios.

**Qué pasó** – La NASA lanzó un Kit para Bibliotecarios que les ayuda a organizar eventos sobre ciencia ciudadana de la NASA. El kit incluye guías para planificar, carteles para anunciar, agendas para seguir y folletos sobre proyectos de la NASA. Está pensado para personas desde los 8 años y sirve para bibliotecas urbanas y rurales, grupos de jóvenes y comunidades de adultos mayores.

**Impacto** – Este kit facilita que bibliotecarios y educadores acerquen la ciencia de la NASA a sus comunidades, incluso donde hay pocas actividades científicas. Quienes lo han usado dicen que les ayuda a ofrecer nuevas oportunidades de aprendizaje y a entusiasmar a más gente con la ciencia espacial.

**Próximo paso** – Bibliotecarios y líderes comunitarios pueden comenzar a usar el kit para realizar eventos de ciencia ciudadana. La NASA también ofrece un video para guiarlos. Esto podría motivar a más personas, especialmente jóvenes, a participar en trabajos científicos reales con la NASA.

**Frase clave** – El nuevo kit de la NASA ayuda a los bibliotecarios a hacer que los proyectos de ciencia ciudadana sean accesibles y divertidos en todas las comunidades.
